text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with lemon ice that's right i'm
going to show you my take on this
classic summertime shaved ice dessert
although there's going to be no shaving
involved because we're going to use the
classic italian granita technique which
only sounds exotic and difficult
basically if you're able to stir with a
fork you're going to be fine well
actually you have to be able to heat up
some water also but if you could pull
off those two things this very simple
and incredibly refreshing dessert can be
yours so let's go ahead and get started
and the first thing we're going to need
is almost a cup of sugar or I'm going to
call for 7/8 of a cup which by the way
is almost unheard of people always will
say 3/4 of a cup plus 2 tablespoons but
anyway I'm going to go with 7/8 which
like I said it's a little unusual so I
thought I would give you a look at it
and what we'll do is add that to some
nice fresh cold water in a saucepan
because the first and pretty much only
step here is dissolving that sugar in
the water over medium heat and we've all
heard that joke about someone being such
a bad cook they can't boil water
well even those people can make this
because this doesn't even need to come
to a boil or even a simmer just give it
a couple stirs with the whisk while your
water heats up and as soon as that
mixture is clear you're done that is it
so the water will get hot but it does
not need to simmer and then once that's
been accomplished we'll remove that from
the heat and while it's still warm we
will add some freshly grated lemon zest
and the exact amount is going to be up
to you but I generally add between 1 and
2 tablespoons and not only is this going
to add some obvious lemon flavor but
without it this mixture is going to be
pretty much colorless so it's also going
to help give our lemon ice a little bit
of a yellow hue so we will go ahead and
add some lemon zest and then what we
want to do is let this cool down to room
temp before we add our freshly squeezed
lemon juice and for this recipe you're
going to need exactly one cup oh and as
far as the tip goes don't forget to zest
your lemons before you squeeze them oh
I've tried it the other way around and
it doesn't really work very well but
anyway we're going to squeeze 1 cup of
fresh lemon juice although it looks like
I'm slightly over and if that happens to
you also what I like to do is make one
whiskey sour and then boom all of a
sudden you have the perfect amount again
but anyway like I said we're going to
need 1 cup of freshly squeezed lemon
juice and assuming that our water sugar
mixture is now room temp we can
move on to final production and all that
means is adding one teaspoon of lemon
extract which is technically optional
but like most of my optional ingredients
I really hope you put it in and then
we'll finish this up by pouring in our
fresh lemon juice and we will take a
whisk and give that a stir
and be careful don't lose all your zest
on the whisk and then what we'll do as
soon as that's mixed up is pour it into
some kind of casserole dish in which we
will freeze it so I believe this is like
a nine by thirteen or nine by twelve
dish but really anything similar is
going to work and I'm not exactly sure
why but before I transfer this into the
freezer I like to mix around the zest a
little bit so it's not all in one spot
since we're going to be mixing this it
probably makes no difference at all but
it makes me feel better and as soon as
that's mixed we'll go ahead and transfer
that into our freezer where we will
begin what I call the granita technique
and all that means is waiting for ice to
start to form and as soon as it does
we're going to mix it around with a fork
every twenty to thirty minutes so this
is what might look like after about 40
to 45 minutes you can see the mixture
starting to freeze around the outside
around the outside around the outside
and what we'll do is take a fork and
kind of break it up and mix it in and
once that's been accomplished we'll
simply put that back in the freezer and
keep repeating that step like I said
every 20 to 30 minutes until it reaches
our desired texture and by the way how
far you go is going to be up to you you
are after all the Reince Priebus of how
your lemon ice freezes some folks prefer
it a little bit softer and slushy
whereas other people like me like to go
fully frozen so it's much more like
shaved ice and I'm not sure if you're
able to see him or not but as I'm
stirring this I see a couple very tiny
seeds that got through the lemon
squeezer which reminds me of something
funny my father told me a long time ago
he was from New York and that's where I
first had this from a street vendor and
he'd tell me that even though they used
artificial concentrate to make this with
whenever they would open up a new tub
they'd squeeze a couple fresh lemons
over the top including the seeds and
they'd mix that in so that every once a
while someone would get a seed in their
cup what you think would be a bad thing
but it wasn't because as soon as someone
finished complaining about getting a
seed in their cup they would always say
the same thing
hey at least that guy uses fresh lemons
which you have to admit is a very New
York story so whenever I make this stuff
I always think of my dad
have a little chuckle but anyway like I
said we're going to keep repeating that
process freezing it for about 20 to 30
minutes taking it out giving it a proper
forking and then popping it back in the
freezer and we will simply continue that
until we're happy with the texture and
one sort of interesting thing here is
the mixture has kind of a yellow color
to it but that's sort of an illusion
because the mixture is actually almost
clear
what you're seeing is that yellow from
the lemon zest reflected and refracted
through those ice crystals which is
giving it that appearance so as you'll
see when we scoop this up
it actually looks almost like snow but
anyway I kept to freezing in a fork in
until it looked a little something like
this at which point we can serve or just
keep in the freezer until needed which
I'm going to pretend is right now so let
me go ahead and serve some of this up
and while I think this looks absolutely
gorgeous as is because I have to take
some pictures I garnish the top a little
extra lemon zest and like I say whenever
you're garnishing something you always
let things fall naturally don't try to
arrange things otherwise it'll look
contrived although this one piece is a
little low let me just move that up on
top that's better so anyway we'll finish
up a little more zest and that's it our
lemon ice is done and looking
extraordinarily refreshing and enticing
so let me grab a spoon and dig in and
because like I said these ice crystals
are almost colorless there's kind of an
optical illusion where your eyes tell
your brain this is just going to be ice
crystals and they're going to have no
flavor but once it hits your palate your
tongues like hey eyes don't you ever get
tired of being wrong because this very
vibrant bright sweet tart flavor
explodes in your mouth so I guess what
I'm trying to say is it's going to taste
like a hundred times more intense than
it looks which is a very cool effect pun
intended so basically what we have here
is a snow cone meets the best lemonade
you ever had and I know there's a lot of
you out there thinking that looks great
but should night Jers over a shot of
vodka well I'm glad you asked yes yes
you should so whether you're an expert
cook or one of those I can't boil water
people I mentioned earlier I really do
hope you give this a try soon so head
over to food wishes calm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual
and as always enjoy
